Highly selective hydrodesulfurization of gasoline on unsupported Co-Mo sulfide catalysts: Effect of MoS2 morphology Ping Li a b Yandie Chen a Cen Zhang a Baokun Huang a Xinyi Liu a Tiefeng Liu a Zongxuan Jiang a ⁎ Can Li a ⁎ 1 a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences,457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 URL: http://www.canli.dicp.ac.cn. Graphical abstract To remove sulfur-containing molecules from gasoline via hydrodesulfurization (HDS) while minimizing olefin hydrogenation is quite difficult. In this work, we report that an unsupported Co-Mo catalyst can achieve high HDS activity with low activity in olefin hydrogenation. The HDS selectivity of the Co-Mo catalyst is fourfold that of CoMo/γ-Al2O3 for both model gasoline and full-range FCC gasoline. For Co-Mo sulfide catalysts, we found that the MoS2 slab morphologies such as curvature, stacking number and slab length were important factors influencing the catalytic performance. Co-Mo catalyst with longer slab length and higher stacking number of MoS2 exhibited higher HDS selectivity. Nevertheless, it was found that the slab length showed much more influence on HDS selectivity than the stacking number. Furthermore, the curved MoS2 could facilitate the olefin isomerization. Present work provides a new way to develop a highly selective HDS catalyst by controlling the MoS2 morphology. Keywords FCC gasoline Selective hydrodesulfurization Cobalt hydroxide carbonate Unsupported catalyst Thiophene HDS 1 Introduction Clean gasoline (S<10ppm) production as a subject of environmental catalysis has received wide attention in recent years. The sulfur content of 85–90% in final gasoline pool comes from FCC naphtha occupying the 30–40 vol.% of commercial gasoline [1–3]. The sulfur compounds in FCC naphtha are mainly small molecules [1] and are easily removed by increasing the severity of the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process. However, the olefins (20–40wt.%) presented in the stream are significantly saturated leading to the loss of the octane number as well as the increase of hydrogen consumption. Therefore, the subject of gasoline HDS is, on one hand to achieve the deep desulfurization and on the other hand to suppress the olefin hydrogenation. To accomplish the requirements of high HDS and low hydrogenation, catalysts with a high HDS selectivity should be developed. HDS of sulfur compounds and hydrogenation of olefins might take place at different catalytic active sites [4–7], which allows designing the catalyst structure to increase the HDS selectivity while suppressing the olefin hydrogenation. It is well-known that the active phase of the HDS catalysts is composed of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) promoted with cobalt and/or nickel sulfides. Various approaches have aimed to improve the HDS selectivity by adjusting the catalyst morphology and catalytic active sites [1,8–14]. Using modifiers (Mg, K) and different supports, Fan et al. [15] studied the effect of supported MoS2 slab morphology on the HDS selectivity of FCC gasoline, and proposed that high dispersion and low stacking of MoS2 increased the number of active adsorption sites for olefins and promoted the olefin hydrogenation, while high stacking and low dispersion of MoS2 decreased the accessibility of sulfur adsorption and resulted in unsatisfactory HDS activity and selectivity. Li et al. [16] found that the HDS selectivity was linearly correlated with the slab length (or the ratio of edge/corner) of (Co)MoS2 phases after investigating a series of CoMo catalysts with different supports. Additionally, the “inflection” on the basal plane similar to the “rim” sites of MoS2 microdomains was associated with HYD active sites [17]. In summary, the current study suggests that the dispersion, the stacking number, the slab length and the degree of curvature of MoS2 slabs affect the HDS selectivity. The morphology of supported MoS2 slabs is generally adjusted by supports and/or modifiers [15,16]. However, the surface acid sites of supports always contribute to the adsorption and isomerization of olefins [18–20] and change the electronic properties of MoS2 and CoMoS2 phases [21]. Moreover, K and Mg modifiers also impact the HDS selectivity [9]. Unsupported catalysts, like NEBULA catalyst and trimetallic NiMoW catalyst, could easily avoid this effect [22–24]. However, such bulk catalysts were always employed for the hydrotreating of diesel and residual oil due to their high hydrogenation activity [23] or used to study the MoS2 morphology [25]. Little attention was paid to the selective HDS of gasoline on the bulk catalyst. In our previous work, we studied a bulk catalyst based on defect-rich MoS2 precursors for selective HDS [26]. Here, we developed a new method to prepare highly selective unsupported Co-Mo catalyst with different MoS2 slab morphology (slab length, stacking number and curvature) by using cobalt hydroxide carbonate as precursor followed by ion-exchange reaction. The Co-Mo catalyst exhibited a higher HDS selectivity for both model gasoline and full-range FCC gasoline compared with supported CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and a higher HDS conversion in contrast to bulk CoMo reference catalyst. Moreover, this catalyst could ensure the production of hydrotreated FCC gasoline with less than 10ppm of sulfur and minimum octane loss (<0.5 point). In addition, the correlation between the MoS2 morphology and HDS selectivity without support effect was briefly discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Unsupported Co-Mo catalysts were prepared by two steps: the synthesis of cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursor (hereafter referred to as Co precursor) and the ion-exchange reaction between Co precursor and molybdate anions. Layered hydroxide salts have exchangeable interlayer anions which can be easily ion-exchanged by molybdate anions [23,27]. Additionally, the cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursor can provide Co promoter for Co-Mo catalyst. 2.1.1 Synthesis of cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursors All chemicals were analytical grade and were used as purchased without further purification. Co precursors with different morphologies were prepared. Rod-shaped Co precursor (labeled as Rod-Co) was synthesized by adding 20ml of 1.22M Na2CO3 into 40ml of 0.50M Co(OAc)2·4H2O mix solution of deionized water and ethylene glycol (1:1v/v) at 100°C and then aged 1h. Belt-shaped Co precursor (labeled as Belt-Co) was prepared according to method reported elsewhere [28]. Typically, a solution of 200ml of 0.20M Na2CO3 was added into 60ml of 0.33M of Co(OAc)2·4H2O ethylene glycol solution at 165°C, and the precipitate was further aged 1h. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Co-Mo catalysts Unsupported Co-Mo oxide catalysts were obtained by ion-exchange reaction between Co precursors and molybdate anions (Mo7O24 6−) for 24h, then followed by filtration, dried at 105°C and calcination under air at 380°C with a heating rate of 3°C/min. The catalysts were denominated as Rod-CoMo or Belt-CoMo according to their precursors. Since some residual Mo anions in filtrate make a difference in the Co/Mo atomic ratio of Co-Mo catalyst, the filtration step was replaced by an evaporation step, and the corresponding catalysts were labeled as Rod-CoMo-Eva or Belt-CoMo-Eva, respectively. Additionally, the ion-exchange time between Rod-Co precursor and molybdate anions had been strictly controlled as 1h, 5h, and 24h to adjust the morphology of MoS2 slabs. The obtained catalysts were noted as Rod-CoMo–1h, Rod-CoMo–5h and Rod-CoMo–24h (simplified as Rod-CoMo), respectively. Moreover, a low heating rate (0.5°C/min) of calcination was also used and the catalyst was noted as Rod-CoMo-Low. A conventional CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst containing 2.7wt.% of CoO and 9.3wt.% of MoO3 was prepared as a reference catalyst by co-impregnation method [29]. Moreover, an unsupported CoMo reference catalyst (labeled as CoMo-Ref) was synthesized by calcination of CoMoO4 hydrates prepared in a mix solution of deionized water and ethanol [30]. Before the catalytic performance tests, all oxide catalysts were sulfided in-situ at 400°C with a H2S/H2 mixture (10/90, v/v) for 2.5h. The reaction conditions were the same without special statement. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a Rigaku D/Max-2500/PC powder diffractometer using a Cu-Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å) operated at 40kV and 200mA with a scan rate of 5°/min. UV-vis-NIR spectra were recorded between 200 and 1800nm on a Cary 5000 Varian spectrometer. Fourier transformed infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellets. The pellet typically contained 2wt.% sample in KBr. The surface areas were measured on a NOVA 4200e adsorption analyzer by N2 adsorption at −196°C using the BET method. Pore size distributions in the mesopore domain were calculated using the BJH method with the desorption branch of the isotherm. Pore volumes were determined by N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.98. The sulfide samples were degassed under vacuum (at about 10−4 Torr) at 150°C for 6h before adsorption of N2. Elemental composition of Co-Mo oxides was analyzed on an ICP spectrometer (Shimadzu ICPS-8100). The samples were dissolved in aqua regia at room temperature, then diluted with deionized water to the desired concentration (between 1–10ppm for each element) before ICP analysis. XPS spectra were recorded using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer equipped with a (150W) Al Kα monochromatic source (hυ=1486.6eV). The samples were prepared and transferred in argon atmosphere [13], and the binding energies (BE) were corrected by referencing all the energies to the C 1s set at 284.6eV. The Mo 3d, Co 2p and S 2p spectra were analyzed with the software CasaXPS Version 2.3.13, applying a Shirley background subtraction and Gaussian-Lorentzian decomposition parameters with 30/70 Gaussian/Lorentzian proportion. The peak positions of Mo, Co and S involved in different phases were determined according to literatures [13,31,32]. Temperature programmed reduction experiments (H2-TPR) were conducted on a home-made equipment with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using 10mg of catalysts. The oxide samples were pretreated in argon at 300°C for 1h. As the temperature was lowered to 80°C, the argon flow was switched to a H2/Ar (5/95, v/v) flow (50ml/min), and then samples were heated to 900°C with 20°C/min. For the sulfide samples, the pretreated temperature was 150°C, and the samples were heated to 600°C at 10°C/min. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (FEI Tecnai G2 Sprint) was used to characterize the Co-Mo catalysts at different synthesis stages. The MoS2 morphology was characterized by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) on a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin (FEI Company) device with an accelerating voltage of 300 keV, and the images were analyzed with a program Digital Micrograph (Gatan). 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation Catalytic performance evaluation was performed on a continuous flow fixed-bed microreactor. Prior to the reaction, 0.7g of catalyst (20–40mesh) was loaded in the reactor and then presulfided in situ with a H2S/H2 mixture (10/90, v/v) at 400°C for 2.5h under atmospheric pressure. Subsequently, selective HDS reaction of model gasoline was performed at 270°C, 1.0MPa, liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 5h−1, H2/oil volume ratio of 100. The model gasoline, consisted of 132ppm thiophene, 25.0vol.% cyclohexene, 25.0vol.% toluene and 50.0vol.% n-heptane, was fed into the reactor after in situ activation [26]. The products were collected and identified by GC–MS coupling after a stabilization period of 8h. Various hydrocarbon products were quantitatively analyzed by an Agilent chromatograph (GC 6890N) equipped with a 50-m PONA (HP) capillary column and flame ionization detector (FID). The reaction products of cyclohexene were cyclohexane and methylcyclopentene. The thiophene contents in feed and products were quantitatively measured by an Agilent chromatograph (GC 7890) equipped with a 50-m PONA (HP) capillary column and flame photometric detector (FPD) to calculate the HDS activity. The mean standard deviation for catalytic measurements was about 2.5%. Thiophene HDS conversion (HDS%), cyclohexene hydrogenation conversion (HYD%) and cyclohexene isomerization conversion (ISO%) were calculated using the following equations [29,33,34]: (1) HDS ( % ) = S f - S p S f × 100 where Sf and Sp denote the thiophene contents in feed and products, respectively. (2) H Y D o r I S O ( % ) = A i f i A r f r + A i f i + A j f j × 100 where A and f are GC peak area and relative mass correction factor, respectively. The subscripts of r, i (or j) denote the residual cyclohexene, cyclohexane (or methylcyclopentene) in products, respectively. Finally, the HDS selectivity is calculated as the ratio between the conversions of thiophene HDS and cyclohexene HYD (Eq. (3)): (3) H D S s e l e c t i v i t y = H D S H Y D Selective HDS reaction of Huifeng full-range FCC gasoline was carried out in the following conditions: LHSV=1–5h−1, T=270–280°C, P=1.0MPa, H2 Nm3/feed m3 =100–180. Since sulfur content of Huifeng FCC gasoline was less than 50ppm, the thiophene was added to increase the total sulfur content to 108ppm and 202ppm, respectively. The hydrocarbon compositions of feed and products were determined using above Agilent 6890 GC (HP-PONA capillary column) and quantitatively analyzed by PONA analysis software (Research Institute of Petroleum Processing, SINOPEC, China). Research octane numbers (RON) of gasoline and its products were calculated by octane software based on the volumetric percentages and the octane numbers of monomer components. The total sulfur content was determined by Antek 9000S total sulfur analyzer. HDS conversion, HYD conversion and HDS selectivity were calculated by the above Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively, by using the total sulfur content to replace the thiophene content and the olefins content to replace the cyclohexene content. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance 3.1.1 Selective HDS of model gasoline Table 1 presents the catalytic performance of Co-Mo catalysts on model gasoline. Unsupported Co-Mo catalysts exhibit much higher HDS selectivity (above 10) than supported CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (about 4), though the CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows a high HDS conversion at the same reaction conditions due to the better dispersion of active components. Compared with the unsupported reference catalyst (CoMo-Ref), the higher HDS conversions are observed on the Co-Mo catalysts based on Co precursors indicating the superiority of developed Co-Mo catalyst with relatively high HDS conversion and HDS selectivity. Both HDS conversion and HDS selectivity of unsupported Co-Mo catalysts are influenced by the morphology of Co precursors. Rod-CoMo and Rod-CoMo-Eva catalysts with Rod-Co precursors show higher HDS conversions than Belt-CoMo and Belt-CoMo-Eva catalysts with Belt-Co precursors, respectively, while the HDS selectivity depends on the thiophene conversion. For Belt-CoMo catalyst, with increasing the thiophene conversion from about 85% to 96%, HDS selectivity rapidly decreases from about 24 to 11. At almost the same thiophene conversion of 96%, the HDS selectivity of Belt-CoMo catalyst is lower than that of Rod-CoMo catalyst. Those results suggest that high HDS conversion and high HDS selectivity can be obtained on Co-Mo catalysts based on Rod-Co precursors. Note that Belt-CoMo catalyst exhibits unexpectedly cyclohexene isomerization conversion and higher than its own HYD conversion. The filtration and evaporation methods significantly impact the HDS conversion. Rod-CoMo and Belt-CoMo catalysts with filtration method show higher HDS conversions than Rod-CoMo-Eva and Belt-CoMo-Eva with evaporation method suggesting that the filtration method can enhance HDS conversions. Furthermore, HDS conversion and selectivity of Co-Mo catalysts based on Rod-Co precursors are influenced by the ion-exchange time and the heating rate of calcination. Increasing the ion-exchange time of Co-Mo catalysts (Rod-CoMo–1h, Rod-CoMo), the HDS conversion and HDS selectivity are improved, while HDS selectivity of Rod-CoMo–5h is slightly decreased likely due to its relatively high HDS conversion since the olefins are greatly hydrogenated at high HDS conversion [2]. Rod-CoMo-Low catalyst with a low heating rate of calcination exhibits lower HDS conversion and HDS selectivity compared to Rod-CoMo catalyst. Among the unsupported Co-Mo catalysts, Rod-CoMo catalyst has a good balance between HDS conversion and selectivity exhibiting a higher HDS selectivity of 14.6 and a weaker HYD conversion of 6.6% at thiophene conversion of 96%. 3.1.2 Selective HDS of full-range FCC gasoline Selective HDS of Huifeng full-range FCC gasoline was performed on Rod-CoMo and CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The sulfur content in products was maintained to less than 10ppm by adjusting the reaction conditions. The PONA analysis of feed and products is shown in Table 2 . The loss of olefin content over Rod-CoMo catalyst is much lower than that of CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, even though the sulfur content is increased to 202ppm. HDS conversion, olefin HYD conversion and HDS selectivity of different catalysts are displayed in Fig. 1 . Olefin HYD of 7.2% on Rod-CoMo catalyst is lower than on CoMo/γ-Al2O3 with HYD conversion of 24.8% at HDS conversion of 91.9%. Further increase of the sulfur content to 202ppm leads for Rod-CoMo catalyst to a higher HYD conversion of 15.9% at HDS conversion of 95.6%, while the RON loss is less than 0.5 (Table 2). Above all, whatever the feedstocks employed, the unsupported Co-Mo catalyst exhibits a very high HDS selectivity. 3.2 Characterization of Co-Mo catalysts Fig. 2 a shows XRD patterns of Co precursors and ion-exchanged Co-Mo precursors dried at 105°C after filtration or evaporation. Main peaks of all samples can be assigned to the cobalt hydroxide carbonate phase (Co(CO3)0.5(OH)·0.11H2O, JCPDS No. 48-0083) with layered structure, consistent with the characteristic peaks of layered hydroxides [35]. Compared to Rod-Co precursor, the relative intensities of (100), (300) and (450) peaks of Belt-Co are weaker than other peaks reflecting some structural difference between Rod-Co and Belt-Co precursors likely originated from different coordination of Co (II) and anion ligands. Belt-Co precursor possesses relatively strong IR peaks of acetate ligands and more tetrahedral coordination Co (II), while Rod-Co precursor has relatively strong IR peaks of carbonate anions and more octahedral coordination Co (II) as revealed by FT-IR spectra (Fig. S1 in the Supporting information) and UV-vis-NIR spectra (Fig. S2) of Co precursors. For Belt-Co precursor, the acetate anions likely locate in the tetrahedral coordination of Co (II) similar to the layered hydroxide cobalt acetates [36]. After the ion-exchange reaction, the Rod-CoMo-105 sample maintains the original peak positions of Rod-Co precursor, whereas for the Belt-CoMo-105 sample, the (020), (231), (340) and (450) peaks are weakened and even disappeared, while the intensity of (001) peak is relatively increased revealing the structural changes of Belt-CoMo-105 during the ion-exchange reaction. Rod-CoMo-Eva-105 and Belt-CoMo-Eva-105 samples with evaporation method have almost the same diffraction peaks of those samples prepared by filtration method. After the calcination, XRD patterns of Co-Mo oxides are shown in Fig. 2b. All samples present the characteristic peaks of cubic Co3O4 phase (JCPDS No. 43-1003), and the broadening of peaks suggests amorphous or small crystallites of Co3O4. Apart from the Rod-CoMo-Eva, no peaks of bulk CoMoO4 in Co-Mo oxides are detected due to the lower calcination temperature of 380°C as confirmed by XRD in Fig. S3. In addition, the intense stretching vibration bands of bulk CoMoO4 and bulk MoO3 are not detected in Raman spectra of Co-Mo oxides in Fig. S4, but only the stretching vibrations of MoO bonds at about 785cm−1 and MoOCo bonds at 890–900cm−1 are observed suggesting the formation of well dispersed Mo species [37–39]. Additionally, the introduction of Mo anions shifts the vibration of the octahedral CoO6 sites (A1g) to a lower wavenumber related to the interaction between Co and Mo species [40]. For the Rod-CoMo-Eva with evaporation method, a weak peak at 26.5° is likely ascribed to the strongest peak (002) of CoMoO4 (JCPDS No. 21-0868). Furthermore, the evaporation method can facilitate the formation of CoMoO4 especially at high calcination temperature as shown in Fig. S3. Additionally, the Co-Mo catalysts with evaporation method, including Rod-CoMo-Eva and Belt-CoMo-Eva catalysts, show a higher reduction temperature compared with the catalysts with filtration method including Rod-CoMo and Belt-CoMo catalysts (Fig. S5) due to the formation of CoMoO4 as revealed in Fig. S3 [41,42]. After the sulfidation, XRD patterns of Co-Mo sulfides are displayed in Fig. 2c. All peaks can be assigned to MoS2 phase (JCPDS No. 75-1539) and Co9S8 phase (JCPDS No. 65-6801). In addition, for the Co-Mo catalysts with different ion-exchange time (Rod-CoMo–1h and Rod-CoMo–5h) and a low heating rate of calcination (Rod-CoMo-Low), the XRD patterns are similar to those of Rod-CoMo catalyst and are not shown. Fig. 3 shows TEM images of Co-Mo catalysts at different synthesis stages. Clearly, Rod-Co precursor has a rodlike structure with the diameter of 7–15nm and the length of 50–150nm, while Belt-Co precursor consists of aggregates of beltlike crystallites with the length of 300–500nm, the breadth of 40–80nm and the thickness of 8–12nm. After the ion-exchange reaction, the Rod-CoMo-105 keeps the original morphology regardless of filtration or evaporation methods (not shown). In contrast, the Belt-Co precursor has decomposed along the length direction and converted to the irregular nanosheets (Belt-CoMo-105) after ion-exchanged reaction likely because acetate anions in the tetrahedral coordination of Co (II) can be ion-exchanged by Mo anions leading to the structural changes of Belt-Co. Different behaviors of Co precursors agree with their structural difference as discussed in XRD analysis. Additionally, Rod-CoMo sample exhibits a chain-like structure after calcination, and then shows numerously straight MoS2 slabs (black fringes) after sulfidation. Whereas for Belt-CoMo sample, fluffy particles are observed after calcination, and the corresponding MoS2 fringes are randomly stacked and more curved. Results suggest that MoS2 slab morphology of Co-Mo catalysts is influenced by the morphology of Co precursors. For the catalysts with different ion-exchange time and a low heating rate of calcination, their TEM images have no noticeable difference compared with Rod-CoMo catalyst and not shown. Physicochemical properties of Co-Mo sulfides are listed in Table 3 . Unsupported Co-Mo catalysts with filtration method show lower MoO3 contents than Co-Mo catalysts with evaporation method since the incomplete ion-exchange between the anions (such as OH− and CO3 2−) bonded to the cobalt hydroxyl sheets and the Mo anions leads to the loss of Mo anions in the filtrate [23]. Belt-CoMo catalyst exhibits a relatively high MoO3 content because acetate anions in Belt-Co precursor increase the lamellar distance of cobalt hydroxyl sheets promoting the ion-exchange [43]. The Co/Mo atomic ratios are greatly different in bulk and surface of Co-Mo catalysts. The surface Co/Mo ratios analyzed by XPS are lower than the bulk Co/Mo ratios measured by ICP indicating that some Co exist in the bulk. The surface Co/Mo ratios of Belt-CoMo and Belt-CoMo-Eva catalysts with Belt-Co precursors are close to the bulk Co/Mo ratios compared with the catalysts with Rod-Co precursors due to that more Mo anions are located in the interlayer of cobalt hydroxyl sheets of Belt-Co and are more uniformly distributed in final catalysts after calcination and sulfidation. In addition, Belt-CoMo and Belt-CoMo-Eva catalysts show lower surface areas than Co-Mo catalysts based on Rod-Co precursors due to the large pore diameter as revealed by the pore-size distribution in Fig. S6. For the Rod-Co precursor, increasing the ion-exchange time could enhance MoO3 contents from 26.1wt.% of Rod-CoMo–1h to 30.4wt.% of Rod-CoMo, while their surface areas and pore volumes are reduced. Additionally, a low heating rate of calcination slightly improves the surface area of Rod-CoMo-Low catalyst. The sulfidation behavior and the amount of CoMoS phase are related to the catalytic performance of Co-Mo catalysts. Fig. 4 a–c shows the XPS spectra of typical Co-Mo catalysts including Rod-CoMo, Belt-CoMo and Rod-CoMo-Eva. Analysis of the Mo 3d spectrum gives the sulfidation ratio of MoS2, whereas the Co 2p spectrum allows quantifying the proportion of the CoMoS phase. An example of the decomposition of Mo 3d, Co 2p, and S 2p spectra of Rod-CoMo is shown in Fig. 4d–f. Molybdenum can exist as MoS2 (MoIV) located at 228.8±0.1eV (MoIV 3d5/2) and 231.9±0.1eV (MoIV 3d3/2), Mo oxysulfide (MoOxSy, MoV) at 230.1±0.1eV (MoV 3d5/2) and 233.2±0.1eV (MoV 3d3/2), and Mo oxide phase (MoOx, MoVI) at 232.1±0.1eV (MoVI, 3d5/2) and 235.2±0.1eV (MoVI, 3d3/2) [31]. To decompose the Co 2p3/2 spectra, we use one main peak and two associated more or less intense satellite peaks according to the chemical state of cobalt. Furthermore, the same methodology has been applied for all the catalysts and thus affords a relatively valuable comparison between them. Cobalt can exist as Co9S8 located at 778.2±0.1eV (Co 2p3/2), CoMoS phase at 778.9±0.1eV (Co 2p3/2) and CoII oxide at 781.3±0.1eV (Co 2p3/2). In addition, sulfur can exist as S2− located at 161.6±0.1eV (S2− 2p3/2) and 162.8±0.1eV (S2− 2p1/2), and MoOxSy phase (S2 2−) at 162.4±0.1eV (S2 2− 2p3/2) and 163.6±0.1eV (S2 2− 2p1/2). Table 4 summarizes the atomic percentages of all the species obtained by the decomposition. For Co-Mo catalysts based on different Co precursors, the MoIV species represent 76% of the total Mo in Rod-CoMo catalyst, while about 68% for Belt-CoMo catalyst. Furthermore, Belt-CoMo catalyst shows a high percentage of MoV (MoOxSy) implying that the Mo species of Belt-CoMo catalyst are more difficult to convert to sulfides compared to Rod-CoMo catalyst. In the case of the Co species, a high proportion of CoMoS phase is obtained on Rod-CoMo catalyst, in which 16% of the cobalt atoms are engaged, while this phase is about 12% for Belt-CoMo catalyst. In addition, a high proportion of S2 2− (MoOxSy) is measured on Belt-CoMo in accordance with the above MoV (MoOxSy). For Rod-CoMo-Eva catalyst, the MoIV proportion and CoMoS proportion are closed to those of Rod-CoMo catalyst. TPR profiles of typical Co-Mo sulfide catalysts in Fig. 5 show the similar characteristic peaks associated to a well-resolved peak at relative low-temperature originating from weakly bound sulfur atoms at the catalyst surface and a broader feature at higher temperature corresponding to the partial reduction of the small MoS2 crystallites [44]. The reduction peak of Belt-CoMo located at about 245°C is lower about 30°C than that of Rod-CoMo catalyst revealing the weakening of the metal-sulfur bond strength of Belt-CoMo catalyst due to bending effects [25]. In addition, the lower peak area of Belt-CoMo catalyst is related to the lower surface area and lower sulfidation degree as revealed by XPS analysis since this peak is originated from the surface sulfur atoms [44]. 3.3 Morphology of MoS2 slabs on Co-Mo catalysts The sulfidation degree and CoMoS phase are related to the HDS activity, while the HDS selectivity is more influenced by the MoS2 morphology [26,45]. To clearly observe the morphology of MoS2 slabs, representative HRTEM images of Co-Mo sulfides are shown in Fig. 6 . The black thread-like fringes (arrow) correspond to the MoS2 slabs with an interplanar spacing of 6.2–6.3Å. By comparison of CoMo/γ-Al2O3, it can be observed that unsupported Co-Mo catalysts exhibit a longer MoS2 slab length. Additionally, the MoS2 stacking number is increased with the increase of ion-exchange time from the Rod-CoMo–1h to the Rod-CoMo catalyst due to more ion-exchanged Mo for the long reaction time. The MoS2 fringes of Belt-CoMo are more curved, while those of Rod-CoMo-Low are slightly short. Quantitative comparison of MoS2 slabs on Co-Mo catalysts was made by statistical analysis of the length and the stacking number of MoS2 for more than 500 stacked MoS2 unit from different parts of each sample. Fig. 7 shows the statistical distribution of the MoS2 slabs in stacking number and length. Obviously, the Co-Mo catalysts with shorter ion-exchange time show a decrease of both high stacking number in Fig. 7a and long slabs in Fig. 7b, while the average stacking number is more influenced as revealed in Table S1. From Fig. 7c–d, it can be seen that both Belt-CoMo and Rod-CoMo-Low catalysts exhibit a lower stacking number and a shorter slab length than Rod-CoMo catalyst. Obviously, the average slab length is more affected than average stacking number by different Co precursors and the low heating rate of calcination (0.5°C/min). 3.4 Catalyst performance-structure correlation From Figs. 2 and 3, the formation process of Co-Mo catalysts is proposed and shown in Scheme 1 . Cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursors are obtained by co-precipitation method, then these precursors can react with Mo7O24 6− anions by interfacial ion-exchange [23]. This process is definitely not a simple impregnation due to a high MoO3 content and well-dispersed Mo species in final Co-Mo oxides as confirmed by XRD and Raman. After calcination and sulfidation, straight or curved MoS2 fringes of Co-Mo sulfide catalysts are obtained due to the different morphologies of Co-Mo oxides which are influenced by Co precursors. The morphologies of Co precursors are mainly affected by two competitive reactions in cobalt acetate solution, hydrolysis by OH− and precipitation by CO3 2−, which can be controlled by the precipitant (CO3 2−) concentration and reaction temperature. The hydrolysis of cobalt acetate in pure ethylene glycol is the main reaction during the initial stage of co-precipitation [28], especially in the low concentration of basic precipitant leading to the layered structure of cobalt hydroxide carbonate with more tetrahedral coordination Co (II) and strong peaks of acetate anions as confirmed by UV-vis-NIR spectrum and FT-IR of Belt-Co precursor. In contrast, high precipitant concentration and low reaction temperature in the mix solution of deionized water and ethylene glycol can facilitate carbonate precipitation reaction accompanying the rodlike cobalt hydroxide carbonate [46]. From Tables 1, 3 and 4, we can find that unsupported Co-Mo catalysts have high HDS selectivity despite poor HDS conversion compared with CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst likely because the CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst has a high surface area and a highly dispersed MoS2 with lower stacking number and shorter slab length. However, for unsupported Co-Mo catalysts, the HDS conversions are not closely related to their surface areas due to the anisotropic MoS2 crystallites. The Rod-CoMo catalyst with 29m2/g has a thiophene conversion of 96%, while it is only about 91% for Rod-CoMo–1h with 42m2/g. From Tables 1 and 4, it can be found that the HDS conversions of Rod-CoMo and Belt-CoMo catalysts are associated with the sulfidation degree of Co-Mo catalysts and the amount of active CoMoS phase. The lower HDS conversion of Belt-CoMo catalyst is likely due to a lower MoIV species and less CoMoS phase compared with Rod-CoMo. The HDS selectivity of Belt-CoMo at close thiophene conversion is also lower than that of Rod-CoMo catalyst originating from the shorter MoS2 slab length of Belt-CoMo (Table S1) which can expose more corner sites and less edge sites, leading to the high hydrogenation activity because corner sites can catalyze the both HDS and HYD reaction while edge sites can only catalyze HDS reaction [42,47]. In addition, the high cyclohexene isomerization conversion of Belt-CoMo catalyst is likely related to the acidic character of −SH group created at the curved MoS2 fringes (Fig. 6d) under H2 atmosphere [25] due to the weakening metal-sulfur bond as revealed in TPR profiles in Fig. 5. Additionally, HDS conversion of Rod-CoMo-Eva catalyst is slightly lower than Rod-CoMo catalyst likely due to the decreased CoMoS phase (Table 4) [48]. The HDS selectivity is not only influenced by the CoMoS phase, but also significantly affected by the MoS2 morphology [26,45]. From Tables 1, S1 and Fig. S7, it can be observed that the HDS selectivity of Co-Mo catalysts is not regularly influenced by the stacking number of MoS2, similar to the selectivity of thiophene HDS pathways, where DDS pathway and HYD pathway of thiophene conversions are not greatly impacted by the degree of stacking [49]. However, HDS selectivity is greatly influenced by the MoS2 slab length as shown in Fig. 8 approaching a linear relationship approximately. Note that the slab length of CoMo/γ-Al2O3 can also be located on the line suggesting that the HDS selectivity is closely related to the slab length of MoS2 regardless of supported or unsupported CoMoS catalysts [16,26,29]. Generally, the corner sites can catalyze both the HDS and HYD reactions because of its higher degree of coordinative unsaturation than that of edge sites caused by easy molecular hydrogen adsorption and dissociation into atomic hydrogen and much easier sulfur removal [47]. The Co-Mo catalysts with longer slab length expose less corner sites, thus having lower hydrogenation activity and higher HDS selectivity. 4 Conclusions In summary, we prepared an unsupported Co-Mo sulfide catalyst where the morphology of MoS2 slabs is affected by the Co precursors and synthetic conditions such as ion-exchange time and heating rate of calcination. HDS selectivity of Co-Mo catalyst is fourfold that of CoMo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for both model gasoline and full-range FCC gasoline at close HDS conversion. It is found that the long MoS2 slabs of Co-Mo catalysts facilitate the HDS selectivity approaching a linear relationship approximately. Additionally, curved MoS2 slabs contribute to the isomerization conversion of cyclohexene. This work provides a new strategy to design highly selective HDS catalyst by controlling the active phase structure. coredata.dc:description: To remove sulfur-containing molecules from gasoline via hydrodesulfurization (HDS) while minimizing olefin hydrogenation is quite difficult. In this work, we report that an unsupported Co-Mo catalyst can achieve high HDS activity with low activity in olefin hydrogenation. The HDS selectivity of the Co-Mo catalyst is fourfold that of CoMo/γ-Al2O3 for both model gasoline and full-range FCC gasoline. For Co-Mo sulfide catalysts, we found that the MoS2 slab morphologies such as curvature, stacking number and slab length were important factors influencing the catalytic performance. Co-Mo catalyst with longer slab length and higher stacking number of MoS2 exhibited higher HDS selectivity. Nevertheless, it was found that the slab length showed much more influence on HDS selectivity than the stacking number. Furthermore, the curved MoS2 could facilitate the olefin isomerization. Present work provides a new way to develop a highly selective HDS catalyst by controlling the MoS2 morphology.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective hydrodesulfurization of gasoline on unsupported Co-Mo sulfide catalysts: Effect of MoS2 morphology
